This one is for all those who send me their love through emails and comments. I do apologise for not replying to them. The only time I do have is to actually sit and read them. And seriously, you guys are just amazing. Keep them flowing.

Just a quick question. Would you like to have a post from Sameer‚Äôs POV? let me know, comment below or email me surtidiaries@gmail.com. Any other ideas welcome. would love to hear from you.

Enjoy.

Most people get married believing a myth that marriage is beautiful box full of all the things they have longed for; Companionship, intimacy, friendship etc ‚Ä¶ The truth is, that marriage at the start is an empty box, you must put something in before you can take anything out. There is no love in marriage, love is in people, and people put love in marriage. There is no romance in marriage, you have to infuse it into your marriage. A couple must learn the art, and form the habit of giving, loving, serving, praising, of keeping the box full. If you take out more than you put in, the box will be empty.

It‚Äôs been two months since our nikah and so far so good. As per every single marriage known to man, we had to return to some sort of routine. and we did, eventually. Be it a good or bad thing, The madressa found a teacher not long after I took my two weeks leave and I was officially no longer a ‚Äúmadressa apa‚Äù. Part of me was saddened but a part of me felt a little okay with it. I needed to settle down in my new home and new life and leaving home to teach something I wasn‚Äôt fully qualified for didn‚Äôt seem suitable. I was not qualified for the job and she was. Seemed to me a fair deal. I was sad though, teaching was actually a great learning experience for me. Safiyya suggested I join the morning madressa and who knows maybe I will. Right now though, I needed to get myself trained to be a wife. Which is, harder than I expected.

I know its all clich√© and everything but let‚Äôs be honest, marriage is definitely not a bed of roses. Okay, marriage is, being a wife isn‚Äôt. I can think of billions of fairy tales where they teach you exactly what happens when you meet a guy, each with different storylines and different characters. But, every one of them have the two same things in common, once upon a time and happily ever after. But I think that‚Äôs where the problem stems. Because they don‚Äôt tell you anything about what happens after. It‚Äôs all up to you to find out. And that is where your true journey begins. That is the real once upon a time.

I turned around as fast as I could and slammed my fist on the alarm clock. The room fell silent and with a sigh I closed my eyes again.

Me: Imz! Get up! (Yawn) it‚Äôs Tuesday! You have a meeting remember?

Imraan shot out of bed and ran into the bathroom. Three minutes later he came out, gave me a kiss and went back in the shower. Lazily, I got up to make his lunch. Once I brushed my teeth and washed my face I was fresh. Thank goodness. I baked him mini pizza‚Äôs and fried a few samosas. Then I made our breakfast. I liked to just have coffee and cake and he was everyday different, according to him whatever I felt he would like. Trust me, it might be cute and everything but it is really pressurising.

Imraan: (walking in) you just know exactly what I want every single day. It‚Äôs like you can read my mind.

Me: and you just know how to flatter a girl.

Imraan: not just any girl (wink)

He walked to me and put his arms around my neck. I blushed.

Me: (lump in my throat) Imraan, I am trying to make fast here. You going to be late.

Imraan: don‚Äôt stress yourself out. It doesn‚Äôt matter if I‚Äôm late.

Me: really? (Raised eyebrow)

Imraan: no. but I will be late for you. Any day.

Me: aw how sweet. You are definitely wearing the charming shirt today.

Imraan: (looking at his shirt) you like it? (Smirk)

Me: stop it.

Imraan: stop what? (Smirk) huh? (Wider smirk) huh?

Me: (getting redder) Imraan!

He laughed at his success to make me blush and let me make the rest of the egg. That was his job every day. To annoy me until I blush. You would think that I would get used to it and stop blushing but no. it just gets worse every day. He is a charmer. And I am a softie, what can I say?

Once imraan had his breakfast which should I mentions was orange juice with two sunny side up eggs, cheese, polony and mushrooms, I opened for him to go. He tried to kiss me goodbye but I kept moving my face and he missed. But I am not as fast as him and eventually he got it. Once I closed the door, my fun for the morning was over. Now begins the even more fun. Not.

Thankfully, I had a housekeeper who helped with the work. In fact she did most of the work. All I did was make the bed, my mother was very particular about making sure I learnt that from little, and cook. Well learn to cook at least. Once imraan left for the office, I jumped back in bed for another hour of sleep. Don‚Äôt look at me with those judgey eyes. I got up again when Silvia (housekeeper) rang the bell and that was when my training to be a better cook began. The same as every weekday besides Fridays- Imraan is off and we have lunch at his parents‚Äô house.

I was already getting the hang of cooking like a pro. Who would have thought that YouTube could be such a good cooking instructor? Okay I lie, I‚Äôm terrible. Even with a ton of YouTube tutorials. It sucked not to have someone there to take over when you were struggling or to fry the puri when you rolled it out. Helping in the kitchen is one thing, but doing everything yourself? Not very easy when you spoilt. There were so many days when I wished I came from a background that made me work. It would have been so much easier.

YouTube was there to show you but not to do. I had this idea last night while going through some of the recipes. Why don‚Äôt I try macaroons? The recipe seemed fairly easy and it couldn‚Äôt be that bad to make right. Right?

*two hours later*

Making macaroons is probably the worst idea for an almost beginner. I whipped the mixture one more time, poured it into a piping bag I made and started to make circles on my baking tray just like the recipe said. One or two leaked a little and touched but I used a fork to scrape it and separate it. I popped it into the oven and with a huge sigh of relief, I stood up. Two hours, I thought, this better come out good!

My thoughts were snapped away by the loud shrill on the phone. I put down the bowl I was about to wash and drying my hands on my apron, ran to answer.

Me: as salaamu alaikum.

Maseeha: (cheerful voice) wa alaikum salaam sister in law. How‚Äôs it going?

Me: all good alhamdulillah mas! And your side? You never going to drop the whole sister in law thing are you?

Maseeha: nope! I‚Äôm not. All is good here too alhamdulillah.

I heard Naseema screaming in the background, ‚Äúwill you cut to the chase and ask her already!‚Äù

Me: ask me what?

Maseeha: well we were just wondering if maybe we could you know come and chill by your place? That is only if you know, you don‚Äôt have a problem with us being there.

Me: (laughing) you asking? You guys know that I‚Äôm still your best friend right? You don‚Äôt have to ask to visit me!

Maseeha: yeah we know that but we thought maybe you need some‚Ä¶some space and‚Ä¶You know you married now and‚Ä¶

Me: (laugh) just get yourselves here. I will be grey by the time you decide what to say.

Naseema: (in background) sabs!! She said we can come!!

Me: sabs? As in Sabeeha?

Maseeha: yeah she came last night. Didn‚Äôt want to disturb you. She said she has something to tell you also. Do you need anything?

Me: nah, I‚Äôm good (idea coming to mind) on second thought, why don‚Äôt you make breakfast for me.

Maseeha: you didn‚Äôt have breakfast yet? Dude it‚Äôs already‚Ä¶

Me: (cutting her off) I had. I just want your breakfast.

I gave her my breakfast order and put the phone down. Luckily, my macaroons didn‚Äôt burn, I completely forgot about it. It didn‚Äôt come out perfectly but it wasn‚Äôt a flop either. Might as well have been a flop but whatever, I will try harder the next time. Or try harder never. I creamed them with the marshmallow Icing I made and quickly tried to get everything cleaned. Fifteen minutes later, I opened the door to receive the three of them. In swimsuits.

Me: what in the world of marshmallow macaroons?

Naseema: (pushing me aside and walking in) is it just me or am I smelling exactly what you said?

Maseeha: salaams sister in law (I rolled my eyes and she smirked) hmmm (taking a deep breath) that smells amazing! Could it be true? Is Amira really learning to finally do everything herself?

Maseeha placed the huge basket in my hand and walked passed me. Sabeeha tapped my shoulder and also walked in. I just shook my head. Some things just never change.

Me: you know you could have told me you coming swimming!

Maseeha: yeah about that, the idea came to us after we called. Sorry.

Me: do you guys not have lives to live?

Sabeeha: pssht. Wait let me just check. Oops nope. Not us. We didn‚Äôt get married, or get a huge amazing penthouse as a gift, or have annoying friends who crash every now and again at that amazing penthouse which is not that much of a deal if it has so few people in it. So Nah. We don‚Äôt have any lives to live just yet.

Me: drama queen! (I placed the basket on the table and started emptying the Tupperware‚Äôs.) Just turn up the heat there for me. It won‚Äôt take long to get hot.

Sabeeha: wait! Your pool is heated??

Maseeha: (smile) my brother likes to swim at night, even in winter!

Sabeeha: I see! But still! A heated pool! Cool! Mahn this place just keeps getting better and better. Next you going to be telling me you have a Jacuzzi in your bathroom. (I bit my lip) you do? No way! Sweet!

Naseema: so you really made these (studying the macaroons like it was a frog specimen in science class)

Maseeha: ooh yum!

Me: it‚Äôs not grand or anything but I tried. Jazakallah for the breakfast mas!

Naseema: helloww! We also helped!

Me: I can only imagine what a help you two were!

Sabeeha: look who‚Äôs talking, three months back you were all (imitating me) I know how to bake and cook. (Her voice) and now you all (imitating voice) does anyone know how to braise onions? Coz this stuff is really not as easy as I thought. (Her voice)

Me: (scrunching my nose) I don‚Äôt even sound like that!

Sabeeha: yes you do, but seriously though, did you like lose your cooking skills? Maybe it‚Äôs a side effect of marriage!

Naseema: (laughing) that is a good one. Side effect (giggle) side effect of marriage. Nice one sabs. (They high five)

Me: you guys are like preschool kids. Mentally unstable preschool kids.

The doorbell rang and I looked at them confused. Nobody comes during the day on a weekday except for them and they were sitting in my lounge. I got up and went to check. Safiyya strolled in with her pram and Mohammed gurgled excitedly as he kicked his legs.

Maseeha: oh did we forget to tell you that we invited safs too? Maaf.

Me: it seems as though you‚Äôll have forgotten to tell me a lot of things today. Anything else? Maybe a party at my house I was not aware of? (I raised my eyebrow)

Safiyya: (giving me a hug) they said pool party. (To Mohammed in her baby voice) isn‚Äôt my baby. A pool party just for us.

I just shook my head and took Muhammad out of his pram. Everyone awed at his cute baby costume. He looked so adorable. We set the table for breakfast and they all went and sat around the pool while I went to change. We sat at the edge and dipped our feet while Safiyya held Mohammed close to her- who seemed to be loving the warm water- and moved around.

Me: hey sabs. You had something to tell me.

Sabeeha: oh yeah. I had two things actually.

Me: spill away then.

Sabeeha: well you can‚Äôt tell your mother I told you but we are thinking about moving to Durban.

Me: what? That would be amazing. Seriously?

Sabeeha: yes, dad got an offer to transfer and he took it. But it‚Äôs not confirmed yet.

Me: wow, that‚Äôs perfect sabs. But uni?

Sabeeha: yeah a friend of my uncle had a chat with me. He said they will be able to transfer me for second semester so that won‚Äôt be a problem.

Maseeha: you can do that?

Sabeeha: apparently.

We all tuned our heads as naseema came running from the lounge and cannonballed into the pool. Mohammed let out a huge laugh and hiccupped excitedly.

Sabeeha: Yeah and the second thing is not good news.

Me: I don‚Äôt like the sound of that!

Sabeeha: neither do I! I was shopping at Sandton City last week and I was buying myself a milkshake at H√§agen-Dazs and while waiting I just kind of saw him. I swear it was by mistake.

Maseeha: who? Ahmed?

Sabeeha: no! No! Sameer.

Me: Vawda?

Sabeeha: At first I thought, no it can‚Äôt be him. But then I saw that t-shirt. You know the Madrid one with Keylor Navas autograph?

Safiyya: wait who‚Äôs that?

Maseeha: one of the players in Madrid.

Me: I‚Äôm still not getting why this is a bad thing.

Sabeeha: he wasn‚Äôt alone Amira. There was this girl, gorgeous and the works, she was sitting on his lap. It wasn‚Äôt a very good sight if you know what I mean.

Me: are you sure it was Sameer? Sameer Vawda?

Maseeha: I was also not believing her but then I started thinking. Sameer didn‚Äôt come for any of your functions. He didn‚Äôt even visit or call. Or did he?

Me: (shaking my head) but that doesn‚Äôt proof that it was him.

Sabeeha: yeah but why didn‚Äôt he come then? Not even for the wedding?

Me: I don‚Äôt know. To be honest I was also a little worried but his mother told me everything is fine. She was still in iddat so she couldn‚Äôt come and he was out of town‚Ä¶

I stopped midway as I realised what I just said.

Me: oh no.

Sabeeha: I am sorry I had to see him Amira. It was purely by chance.

Amira: hey there is no need for you to be apologising.

Sabeeha: I think he is gone back to his past.

Me: so now? It‚Äôs not like I can even talk him out of anything. He won‚Äôt listen. And plus, it‚Äôs his life. I have nothing to do with it and no right to intervene.

Maseeha: you‚Äôre right. But you also wrong. You know you have an influence on him.

Me: that‚Äôs only because he has a thing for me you guys know that right?

Sabeeha: (widening her eyes) a what? Wait? Sameer has a thing for you? OHMY‚Ä¶WHATINTHE

Me: had. He had a thing. It‚Äôs over now. I hope.

Naseema: how do you know?

Me: I don‚Äôt. That is why I wish to stay out of this. (Holding up my left hand) I‚Äôm married remember?

Mohammed let out a yelp and it sounded like a yes so we all laughed. That broke the ice that was beginning to form in the air. After that maseeha slid in the pool and swam over to Mohammed. She made Sabeeha to bring his sunglasses and blow up ring. She blew it up, put him inside, put on the sunglasses and pushed him lightly. We all cooed. He looked just too cute. I snapped a few pics of him looking like a cool dude.

sabeeha: amira? you cant ignore it. you two were getting quite close what happened?

me: what happened is that I learnt that one is allowed to marry their step sibling, which by the way I didn‚Äôt know. I dont know why but I always thought that a step brother was like a real. And after that I just couldn‚Äôt. I didn‚Äôt want it to start all over again. I had enough boy drama.

maseeha: so you going to ignore it?

me: no. (sigh) you know me. I will call him tomorrow. See what‚Äôs going on. I‚Äôm sure it must just be a one time thing and he will come around. lets just forget about it for now.

I swam towards the edge and grabbed the ball from the side, jumping up, I threw it at sabeeha.

Me: How‚Äôs hajj preparations going saf?

We played all day in the pool. Safiyya got out to bath Mohammed and put him to sleep and then got back in. by the time we got out, it was afternoon and we were all shrivelled up. We had a shower and flocked to the kitchen to make something to eat. The easiest was burgers so we all got together and made our very own recipe burgers. Imraan was home earlier than we thought, thankfully though because we were starved- swimming really makes you hungry. He let himself in and looking at us all shook his head and laughing.

Imraan: I see this has become the den for you‚Äôll.

He came to where I was sitting and gave me a kiss. I blushed red.

Imraan: are they troubling you babe? Coz I will kick them out if you want?

Maseeha: isn‚Äôt that what a sister in law is meant to do? Trouble and make the brother‚Äôs wife a living hell?

I stuck my tongue out at her.

Maseeha: and anyway, how can you kick your sister out. Imagine the headlines, newly wedded couple kicks sister in law out of home.

We all laughed.

Imraan: more like, brother makes a huge mistake and marries sister‚Äôs best friend. Ruined for life.

Me: (pushing him off the couch) hey!

Imraan: aw (wink) no need to stress. You my dear, is my favourite mistake.

Naseema: (throwing the cushion at him) you can do a better stolen quote than that you idiot.

Her outburst set us off on another frantic laugh.

Imraan: (smirk) someone is getting very jealous here. (getting up) anyways, I am going down to the ground floor. I need to check if my maintenance guy came in today. I will be back in the next half an hour, okay babe?

Me: and supper? You not hungry?

Imraan: that is actually a very good suggestion. Let‚Äôs eat first.

So we ended up eating. The burgers came out divine. We actually make a pretty cook team of chefs. Even the chips tasted amazing. Imraan let us be after supper and went down to sort his building stuff out. Before he left he gave naseema the most peculiar look and I made a mental note to ask him later why.

Sabeeha: so guys? I have something to tell you‚Äôll.

Me: good or bad?

Sabeeha: it depends.

Maseeha: can you cut the tension and tell us.

Sabeeha: You remember Yusuf Asmal?

Me: uh yeah‚Ä¶

Sabeeha: he sent a proposal‚Ä¶

salaams. There has been a request for Imraan‚Äôs POV. I am considering it for the next post. let me know what you think.

I know I am very very late, but it‚Äôs still friday right?

enjoy.

If you want something to last forever, you treat it differently. You shield it and protect it. You never abuse it. You don‚Äôt expose it to the elements. You don‚Äôt make it common or ordinary. If it ever becomes tarnished, you lovingly polish it until it gleams like new. It becomes special because you have made it so. And it grows more beautiful and precious as time goes by.

I stared out the window, taking a moment to admire the unflinching ability of the clouds to look like candy floss, and sipped at the water the airhostess had passed me. So this is what it felt like to come home after amazing vacation with your husband. Imraan‚Äôs head was laid back on his seat and I could hear his soft breaths. I covered my mouth to block a huge yawn and lay on the window. The flight just never seemed to end.

I woke up with a shock when someone tapped me. Turning I realized that it was Imraan.

Imraan: we landing.

Me: (yawn) I am so tired.

Imraan: sorry I woke you.

Me: it‚Äôs okay. I‚Äôll sleep when we get home. (Yawn)

There wasn‚Äôt many people that came to meet us at the airport. But when I say not many, I mean not many for an Indian family. Because let‚Äôs be honest, nobody fly‚Äôs in and out of their hometown without having an entire jamaat there. It‚Äôs like a family reunion. At the airport.

So with my eyes half closed, my ears still numb from the pressure of the air and my body jetlagged, I hugged the entire female congregation who were full of smiles and energy. Duh, they didn‚Äôt just fly for an entire day!

We stood at the international arrivals for a really long time and chatted. By the time we left, it was already dark. My family headed home while Imraan and I went home with his parents. We made small talk in the car and they insisted we come home for supper. Imraan started to explain to them that I was tired but I stopped him and agreed.

Me: (walking into the kitchen) what can i help with?

Imraan‚Äôs mother: no no. Nothing to do. Don‚Äôt worry everything is already ready. You must be exhausted. You rest.

Maseeha: yeah amy (sarcastic smile) no stress. You just rest.

I stuck my tongue out at her when her mother turned her back.

My mother in law went out of the kitchen.

Me: (slipping into one of the comfy kitchen stools) not like you doing anything yourself! What you getting jealous of?

Maseeha: me? Jealous? Puhlease! Tell me, how was lilly beach?

Me: that place is amazing mas! Its so beautiful. You have to go there!

Maseeha: well i shall consider it for out annual trip overseas. On to the question everyone is dying to ask you but is scared, how‚Äôs marriage?

Me: can you ask me that question another time. I didn‚Äôt plan that answer yet!

Maseeha just looked at my face with a confused look. Then she started giggling.

Maseeha: my brother married a crazy woman.

Me: you mean your best friend married an amazing guy who happens to have a crazy sister?

Imraan: (calling from the lounge) Amira?

Maseeha: (groan) mahn! Now i have to share you (sigh)

I laughed as i slipped off the stool to find imraan.

We left from the house very late and i could no longer keep my eyes open. I was more exhausted than ever.

As soon as imraan let us in i was crawling up the stairs and heading toward the bedroom. I didnt even wait to see imraan come upstairs. I just needed to sleep.

The next day was the day before the walima. I got up looking like someone hit me in the face with a bowling ball. Imraan walked into the room.

Imraan: good morning sunshine! (Pause) or should i say moonshine!

Me: (sigh) I thought i was the drama queen!

Imraan: and so you are my dear! (Smirk) I‚Äôm the king! (Handing me a mug)

Me: aw you made coffee? (Taking a sip)

Imraan: sorry my queen. I do not have the knowledge to make coffee. However i did make you milo!

Me: (getting choked and spluttering) wait what? (I burst out laughing) you don‚Äôt know how to make coffee? Are you kidding me?

Imraan: (sitting down on the bedroom lounger) no. I might have forgot to buy a few electrical appliances and i have never made coffee accept for from a coffee machine.

Me: (smirk) oh really now?

Imraan: yes. you just press the button and out comes the coffee.

Me: you motalas are too spoilt!

I turned on my side and a striking pain waltzed through my body making me scream in pain.

Me: ow!

Imraan: whats wrong? (Worried look)

Me: i cant move properly. My body is sore.

Imraan: want to go bungee jumping again?

Me: (rolling my eyes) don‚Äôt start again. You gave me enough beans as it is about me making you do bungee.

Imraan: you know you could have chose anything else. Anything. Horse riding, archery, swimming, whale watching. But no, of all the things you choose bungee!

Me: well there was wind surfing?

Imraan: (laugh) i still can‚Äôt believe you actually did that! And you made me do it!

Me: i don‚Äôt regret it. I think i can handle this pain. (I moved again) ow!

Imraan helped me out of bed and i had the quickest shower in my life. My entire neck downward felt paralyzed. Imraan was kind enough to give me a massage (he sucked at it but at least he tried.)

He ordered take out for supper and we both sat on the bed and had pizza, subs and coke. I was out after that.

Imraan: amira! Hey amira!!! We late!

Imraan pulled the duvet out slowly and i tugged it away from him and turned the other way with a groan.

Imraan: amira! We are really late!

Me: for what? (My eyes still closed andy back facing imraan)

Imraan: (stating the obvious) the walima.

Me: the walima. (Pause) our walima.

I shot out of the bed like a spring and sprinted to the bathroom as fast as i could. If I thought the previous days shower was fast, i was wrong.

It was my walima day and I was extremely late. I got ready as fast as I could, running from one side to another to find my stuff. I didn‚Äôt have much time to put much makeup so I just put on the basic stuff and Imraan and I were off. I wore a plain white dress with silver work all down the sleeves. It was simple, free flowing and set like a dream. Imraan wore the grey tuxedo that he was supposed to wear for the nikah.

Me: why didn‚Äôt naseema call? Normally she calls if you like 2 seconds late, this is like half an hour!

I checked my phone. 76 messages. 12 missed calls. Oops.

Sabeeha was standing in the driveway when we pulled in and she quickly helped me to look presentable. We rushed to the backyard and i was greeted by a very ballistic naseema. She was going crazy. we had an entire conversation through gritted smiles, everyone was watching the new bride. To date, I still haven‚Äôt come up with a good enough reason how naseema is my friend.

If i thought her scolding for being late for my own walima was bad, you should have seen her after that.

naseema: OH MY WORD. AMIRA!!! LIFT YOUR DRESS UP!

me: huh?

naseema: YOUR DRESS! LIFT IT UP!!

I obeyed and lifted it up. looking down at myself i realised what she was having a fit about. In that rush, i forgot to wear the shoes that I bought to match the dress. instead, I was wearing a gold pump. Before I could set foot in the garden, she sent me off to maseeha‚Äôs room to find a ‚Äúdecent‚Äô pair of shoes.

The garden setting was breathtakingly amazing. It was marvelously impressive. she divided the garden using a long mirror screen. the mirror made each side look bigger and gave the place a beautiful effect. The sides were lined with mine water features and goldfish bowls. Huge, round tables filled the place up and at the front was three see-through steps that led to a mini pavilion that was decorated with flowers. the table setting was plain and simple and only made everything look so much more elegant. The menu was straight forward, sojee, chicken biryani and roasted chicken with buns. The function was short and sweet and everything was over quickly.

I sat upright against the headboard and maseeha helped to put a pillow behind me. That same afternoon i started burning up and my eyes were watering non stop. naseema was sprawled on the carpet and maseeha took a seat on the leather one man couch. safiyya who just came in looking like she was crying sat at the edge of the bed.

saffiyya: i have good news to tell you‚Äôll!

me: spill! spill!

saffiyya: okay. wait for sabeeha then. shes coming now.

we sat in silence for five minutes and waited. the door swung open and sabeeha strolled in with muhammed in her arms.

maseeha: finally! would you sit already, saf has something to tell us.

sabeeha sat down on the floor against the cupboard.

sabeeha: oooh‚Ä¶tell‚Ä¶tell‚Ä¶tell

saffiyya: (her eyes lighting up) Zaakir and I have been accepted for Hajj!

This post is dedicated to sister Amina who gave me much needed advice. Sister Amina, your advice was much appreciated. Jazakallah.

And for those of you who are reading the blog and not commenting, I would love to hear from you.

Happiness. Happiness is not determined by the cost of your car, or the price of your house. It‚Äôs not determined by the digits on your bank account. And neither is it determined by the once in a year extravagant vacations. Maybe we are fortunate enough to be blessed with such luxuries, but in the end, true happiness is when you can love and be loved. For love, love is the master key that opens the gate of happiness.

And if love is happiness‚Ä¶what could be better than halaal love?
